channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description:
@HistoricalGamer @chrislbs @Unmikely @AlecStapp @cta The Dan Ryan portion of the CTA Red Line runs in the middle of that highway for many miles (from north of 35th/Comiskey Park all the way down to 95th).

The Bishop Ford(?) Expressway was also built with a wide median for the same purpose, but a different route is now planned.
item.source:markdown:
@HistoricalGamer @chrislbs @Unmikely @AlecStapp @cta The Dan Ryan portion of the CTA Red Line runs in the middle of that highway for many miles (from north of 35th/Comiskey Park all the way down to 95th).
The Bishop Ford(?) Expressway was also built with a wide median for the same purpose, but a different route is now planned.

item.description:
@HistoricalGamer @Unmikely @AlecStapp The southern branch of the blue line is in the middle of I-290 - nowhere near an airport of any kind!

I believe it replaced an earlier elevated line on the same right of way that was demolished (along with the surrounding houses) when I-290 was built in the mid-1900s.

@HistoricalGamer @Unmikely @AlecStapp Specifically, the ‘Forest Park’/‘Congress’ branch of today’s @cta Blue Line replaced the Garfield Park branch of the Metropolitan West Side Elevated Railroad.

The Blue line wasn’t extended to O’Hare (along a different highway) until 1984.

https://t.co/h2mlA4nQIV

@ReceiptsIn @ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed An outside observer might think that a nation which won its own independence partially due to ‘unconventional’ (for the time) and ‘uncouth’ guerrilla warfare …

… might have had at least some insight into the impracticality of a long-term occupation of determined populations.

@ReceiptsIn @ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed If only someone would have warned us… https://t.co/w9vHK05nPl

@ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed Yup.

That’s one very good reason you don’t see many battleships out there anymore!

(but when they existed, especially the late-model battleships, they sure were marvels of engineering beauty)

@ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed Modern aircraft carriers are sitting ducks for both torpedoes and guided missiles.

They don’t (can’t) sail anywhere contested without multiple rings of protection (warships, electronic, and aviation), ranging out many hundreds of nautical miles.

@ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed To mangle an old phrase:

“Hypersonic missiles and railguns may be fast, but they’re not faster than Motorola™”

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The first military ‘mines’ were not explosives but rather

… timber-braced tunnels dug underneath stone fortifications, such as castle walls.

(think old-time manual labor coal or silver mine tunnels, with pick-axes and little wooden carts)

1/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Once complete, the wood inside was set on fire, and a few hours/days later the tunnels collapse and undermine the stone walls.

~ ~ ~ ~

Modern naval torpedoes work the same way; they are often set to explode beneath the keel of a large ship, not hit the ship directly.

2/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The resulting shock wave rocks the ship and causes some damage…

… but the real fun starts when the pressure dissipates but before the water can rush back in.

(Spoiler: gas is compressible, water effectively isn’t, and ships are very heavy)

3/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Basically, there’s nothing supporting the center of the ship anymore (aka a nautical sinkhole), and hopefully the now-damaged keel cracks from the uneven support.

~ ~ ~ ~

I imagine bridge piers don’t like their foundations to suddenly ‘blink out of existence’ either.

4/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki (I wouldn’t be surprised if the mere threat of a nearly-completed mined wall had occasionally led to the occupants of besieged fortifications to surrender at the last moment … before the mine was lit afire; averting catastrophic damage)

#NotAHistorian
item.source:markdown:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The first military ‘mines’ were not explosives but rather
… timber-braced tunnels dug underneath stone fortifications, such as castle walls.
(think old-time manual labor coal or silver mine tunnels, with pick-axes and little wooden carts)
1/4
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Once complete, the wood inside was set on fire, and a few hours/days later the tunnels collapse and undermine the stone walls.
~ ~ ~ ~
Modern naval torpedoes work the same way; they are often set to explode ~beneath~ the keel of a large ship, not hit the ship directly.
2/4
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The resulting shock wave rocks the ship and causes some damage…
… but the real fun starts when the pressure dissipates ~but before the water can rush back in~.
(Spoiler: gas is compressible, water effectively isn’t, and ships are ~very~ heavy)
3/4
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Basically, there’s nothing supporting the center of the ship anymore (aka a nautical sinkhole), and hopefully the now-damaged keel cracks from the uneven support.
~ ~ ~ ~
I imagine bridge piers don’t like their foundations to suddenly ‘blink out of existence’ either.
4/4
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki (I wouldn’t be surprised if the mere threat of a nearly-completed mined wall had occasionally led to the occupants of besieged fortifications to surrender at the last moment … before the mine was lit afire; averting catastrophic damage)
#NotAHistorian

item.description:
@CheongieMon @ashleyshaneb @gardenrichard @zahed Straw-reinforced concrete.

It worked for ‘wattle and daub’!
item.source:markdown:
@CheongieMon @ashleyshaneb @gardenrichard @zahed Straw-reinforced concrete.
It worked for ‘wattle and daub’!

item.description:
@daniel_balos @zahed @gardenrichard True, but it’s only about 50 years old, right?

“Soviet bridge; strong like ox.”

Once the now-exposed steel oxidizes, though, and after a few freeze-thaw cycles… long-term it’s probably ‘totaled’.

@stefan_meyer98 @zahed @gardenrichard There are a lot of ways to use it for low volume traffic (far under design loads) in good weather.

Even if damaged much further, it could still serve as a useful foundation / formwork for a temporary bridge (once Ukraine again has control of the area and isn’t under fire).

@stefan_meyer98 @zahed @gardenrichard Risk profiles (even for civilians) are much different in wartime, after all!

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki I wonder if it could be ‘mined’ (in the medieval sense of the term) using some kind of second-hand tunnel boring machine (TBM), or even a oil-rig-style directional boring system…
item.source:markdown: @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki I wonder if it could be ‘mined’ (in the medieval sense of the term) using some kind of second-hand tunnel boring machine (TBM), or even a oil-rig-style directional boring system…

item.description: @Section_131 @mccrackin592 @zahed @ChrisO_wiki A mega-yacht, re-purposed as an explosives delivery vehicle, targeted at speed against one of the bridge tiers might be an interesting thought experiment.
item.source:markdown: @Section_131 @mccrackin592 @zahed @ChrisO_wiki A mega-yacht, re-purposed as an explosives delivery vehicle, targeted at speed against one of the bridge tiers might be an interesting thought experiment.

item.description:
@NobodyK83030025 @ValeenC @zahed Folks can try something similar at home!

By pressing one’s hands inward (post-tensioning), three to five tin cans of food or soda can be suspended horizontally in the air.

(With enough inward force, another person can even apply a mild bit of ‘simulated live load’ to the top.)

@zahed @SigmaBob Plus, all the custom formwork for any prefab segments is likely long gone.

With changes in government, they might not even have complete and accurate construction drawings anymore.

(Small cracks in a major post-tensioned bridge in Seattle has closed it down for years.)

@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?

(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)
item.source:markdown:
@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?
(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)

item.description:
@luckystallard @carlbildt @Andy_Scollick There are constant #ISR flights over the Baltic sea and Romania.

Everything airborne is tracked and logged.

(There are also likely a non-zero number of intelligence imaging satellites tracking likely launch sites in the region.)

@luckystallard @carlbildt @Andy_Scollick (I meant to say “Black sea”, but the same is also mostly true for the Baltic, of course.)

@BenjaminEHowe @jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Depending on ones threat profile, that could be a ‘specific new feature’ to consider, if it promises to patch a specific vulnerability.

For a networked home printer behind a NAT router, or especially a non-networked USB model…
item.source:markdown:
@BenjaminEHowe @jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Depending on ones threat profile, that could be a ‘specific new feature’ to consider, if it promises to patch a specific vulnerability.
For a networked home printer behind a NAT router, or especially a non-networked USB model…

item.description:
@jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Brother is one of the better ones in this regard.

(Also, regardless of brand, it is best to avoid upgrading the firmware of cheap printers unless you’re trying to resolve a specific issue or are promised a specific new feature that is of value to you.)
item.source:markdown:
@jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Brother is one of the better ones in this regard.
(Also, regardless of brand, it is best to avoid upgrading the firmware of cheap printers unless you’re trying to resolve a specific issue or are promised a specific new feature that is of value to you.)

item.description:
@LeadershipNext1 @edwardstrngr ITER is currently scheduled for first plasma operations in next 40 months or so.

With additional funding and other support (such as rallying other scientists to contribute), that and the post-plasma timelines might be able to be quickened.

@iterorg

@CateBelling @melancholynsex @Enfamil @Walgreens Likely the physical cardboard box…

… normally the inside is printed with a color pattern (e.g. geometric, floral, or a just solid color), so if one carefully unfolds the box it can be flipped over and re-folded into an un-branded storage box (e.g. for scarves in a closet).
item.source:markdown:
@CateBelling @melancholynsex @Enfamil @Walgreens Likely the physical cardboard box…
… normally the inside is printed with a color pattern (e.g. geometric, floral, or a just solid color), so if one carefully unfolds the box it can be flipped over and re-folded into an un-branded storage box (e.g. for scarves in a closet).

item.description:
@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure Often that is because component-level parts and schematics are not furnished by the manufacturer.

Even now, (nearly?) every major appliance sold in the US (& for 70+ years), has a schematic hidden inside!

(The same was true for many TVs and radios for much of the past century.)

@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure If there was demand for repair (and parts availability), repair costs would drop with scale.

Many people may also feel more empowered to tinker and learn - even easier now with YouTube - in those down periods, such as after putting the kids to bed for the night.

#RightToRepair

@Curvycutie69 @DouglasNicol8 @natefernald Many old TVs (mostly CRTs and the first decade or so of some flat-panel plasma/LCD models) actually had room for the speakers to be on front, actually facing the room.

Sadly, it appears that ship has sailed.
item.source:markdown:
@Curvycutie69 @DouglasNicol8 @natefernald Many old TVs (mostly CRTs and the first decade or so of some flat-panel plasma/LCD models) actually had room for the speakers to be on ~front~, actually facing the room.
Sadly, it appears that ship has sailed.
